title: Citi and FINLEA Launch 2013 Financial Education Campaign Online Competition
summary: Citi Taiwan and the Financial Literary and Education Association (FINLEA) today launched the 2013 Citi-FINLEA Financial Education Campaign Online Competition for primary school children in grades 3 to 6. This campaign is supported by Citi Foundation.
tag-1: Citi and FINLEA Launch 2013 Financial Education Campaign Online Competition
tag-2: Citi Taiwan and the Financial Literary and Education Association (FINLEA) today launched the 2013 Citi-FINLEA Financial Education Campaign Online Competition for primary school children in grades 3 to 6. This campaign is supported by Citi Foundation.
tag-3: Expected to draw more than 50,000 contestants from across the country, the competition, which runs from March 1 to May 10 this year, will see students vie for scholarships of up to NT$50,000. Students may register for the competition on the event's official website, www.Citi-online-finedu.org.tw, or search online for "Citi online finedu."
tag-4: Contestants will watch 14 online animation videos on money management and take quizzes based on these videos as well as share their thoughts and progress with their teachers.
tag-5: This year, participants will also read "Jinzai's Journal on Accumulating Wealth," an online series of 21 hand-drawn stories centered on good money management habits. Students are expected to use these stories as a model to develop sound financial habits including recording daily expenditures, putting money away on a regular basis and understanding the difference between their needs and wants.
tag-6: Citi Foundation and FINLEA have been working together to improve money management education in Taiwan since 2006. This year, in addition to the competition for students, the organizers will invite elementary school teachers to develop innovative teaching proposals based on the 14 animation videos. Over NT$60,000 in prizes will be offered for teachers with the best proposals to help to further promote financial education in schools.
tag-7: FINLEA President Tze-Kaing Yang said a strong foundation in money education is necessary to face today's complex work and living environment.
tag-8: "Every child should be taught how to master their own finances while learning how to care for and give back to society," Mr. Yang said.
tag-9: Citibank Taiwan's Head of Corporate Affairs Michelle Liao said that teaching money management effectively requires skillful guidance and that kids need to see how it relates to them first-hand.
tag-10: "Therefore, using a three-pronged approach that includes videos, hands-on bookkeeping practice and tests, will help to instill the correct values in them. In addition to making learning fun, we help kids become little financial gurus," Ms. Liao said.
tag-11: The Citi Online Financial Education Campaign was the first online financial education project aimed at primary school children in Taiwan. Citi Foundation has sponsored over NT$21 million for the annual competition jointly organized with FINLEA over the past eight years. The project has trained over 2,000 seed instructors and taught over 300,000 kids. Last year, the competition introduced Taiwan's first online accounting tool for primary school kids, which has recorded almost 20,000 bookkeeping entries to date.

tag-64: Financial Literacy and Education Association The Financial Literacy and Education Association (FINLEA) is the first organization devoted to promoting financial literacy and education in Taiwan. Comprising experts from the financial, educational, publishing and other industries, FINLEA aims at promoting financial literacy and education among the public to foster correct money values and healthy financial concepts. It vows to enhance the public's financial knowledge, reduce the number of financially disadvantaged groups and propel the government and industries to provide a high-quality and friendly financial environment.
tag-65: Since its establishment in 2006, FINLEA has assisted the Cabinet-level Financial Supervisory Commission and the Ministry of Education to promote various financial education projects among students and teachers at elementary, junior, senior and vocational high schools. FINLEA has also teamed up with the Citi Foundation to launch the Young Adult Financial Literacy courses, in hopes of strengthening Taiwanese students' knowledge about money management and financial planning to help them make correct financial decisions after graduation. Additional information may be found at www.finlea.org.tw
